text: <extra_id_0> Glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in patients with lupus nephritis : relationship between receptor levels in mononuclear leukocytes and effect of glucocorticoid therapy .

We investigated the clinical significance of <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> determination in 20 patients with systemic lupus erythematosus ( SLE ) who afterwards developed nephrotic syndrome .

<extra_id_0> Glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> concentrations in mononuclear leukocytes ( MNL ) in these patients were comparable with those in both other patients with SLE and healthy persons .

Improvement in urinary protein excretion and in disease activity , which was scored according to the SLE Disease Activity Index system of the University of Toronto , closely related to the <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> concentrations in MNL isolated from the corresponding patients .

In summary , <extra_id_0> glucocorticoid receptor <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> determination in patients with lupus nephritis may be a predictive clue for assessing responsiveness to glucocorticoid therapy .
